read.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to look at written words and understand what they mean
read.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She picked up the letter and read it.
Read the instructions carefully before you start.
children who are just learning to read and write
Her books are quite widely read (=read by a lot of people).
When I was young, I read every one of his books from cover to cover (=read all of something because you are very interested).
read.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to find out information from books, newspapers etc
read.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: You can’t believe everything you read in the papers.
Did you read about what happened to that guy in Florida?
I was shocked when I read of his death.
I read last week that the disease is on the increase.
read.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to say the words in a book, newspaper etc so that people can hear them
read.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: He glanced at the letter and began to read it aloud.
Daddy, will you read me a story?
Our mother reads to us every evening.
Teachers should read more poetry to children.
read.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to look at signs or pictures and understand what they mean
read.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: He plays the violin very well but can’t actually read music.
Are you any good at map reading?
read.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if a computer can read a disk, it can take the information that is on the disk and put it into its memory
read.translation[0].definitions[5].signp: understand something in a particular way
read.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to understand a situation, remark etc in one of several possible ways
read.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I wasn’t sure how to read his silence.
He had accurately read the mood of the nation.
She shook her head, and I read this as a refusal.
The poem can be read as a protest against war.
read.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: used to say what words are on a sign, in a letter etc
read.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: A sign on the outer door read: ‘No Entry’.
read.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if something reads well, badly etc, it has been written well, badly etc
read.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: I think in general the report reads well.
read.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to look at the number or amount shown on a measuring instrument
read.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Someone should be coming to read the gas meter.
read.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if a measuring instrument reads a particular number, it shows that number
read.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to study a subject at a university
read.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: He wants to read for a law degree.
read.translation[0].definitions[10].note: In everyday British English, people usually say that someone does a subject at university:
He wants to do a law degree.
read.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with read
read.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You read something in a book, newspaper, magazine etc
I read the interview in the newspaper
read something on a book, newspaper, magazine etc
read.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: You read something in  a particular chapter of a book, or in  the introduction
In this chapter you can read about different types of diet
read.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You read something in the instructions or in a recipe
I read in the instructions that you are supposed to boil the pasta for six minutes
read.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: You read something on the Internet or on a website
She read the story on the Internet
read.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: You read something on a page
You can read about his life story on page 12
read.translation[0].note_box[0].items[5]: You read something on a train, bus, plane etc
I like reading on the train – it helps to pass the time
read something in a train, bus, plane etc
read.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: read
to look at and understand the words in a book, magazine, letter etc for interest, enjoyment, or study
What book are you reading at the moment?
I usually read the newspaper on the way to work.
flick/flip/leaf through something
to turn the pages of a book, magazine etc quickly, looking for things that might interest you
While I was waiting, I flicked through a magazine.
She was flipping through the pages of an encyclopedia.
Cunningham was leafing through a copy of the Financial Times at his desk amidst a cloud of cigar-smoke.
browse through something
to spend time looking through a book, magazine etc without any clear purpose, looking for things that might interest you
Would you like to browse through our holiday brochure?
skim/scan (through) something
to read something quickly to get the main ideas or find a particular piece of information
I want you to skim through the article and write a short summary of it.
Tony scanned the menu for a vegetarian option.
pore over something
to read something very carefully for a long time
They spent weeks poring over guidebooks and planning their holiday.
devour something
to read something quickly and eagerly
Her young fans devour her books.
dip into something
to read short parts of something
It’s a book you can dip into rather than read from cover to cover.
plough/wade through something
to read something long and boring
He’s upstairs ploughing through financial reports.
I can’t possibly wade through all this.
surf the Net/Internet/Web
to look quickly through information on the Internet, stopping to read what interests you
He surfed the Net, looking for jobs.
read.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: if you have a read, you spend time reading
read.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I sat down to have a nice quiet read.
I had a quick read of the report before I left.
